cluster.display: __________ estimates an unknown parameter using a single number that has been calculated from the sample.
Point estimation estimates an unknown __________ using a single number that has been calculated from the sample.
Point estimation estimates an unknown parameter using a single number that has been calculated from the __________.
__________ estimates an unknown parameter using an interval of values that is likely to contain the true value of that parameter.
Interval estimation estimates an unknown __________ using an interval of values that is likely to contain the true value of that __________.
Interval estimation estimates an unknown parameter using an __________ of values that is likely to contain the true value of that parameter.
Interval estimation estimates an unknown parameter using an interval of values that is likely to contain the __________ of that parameter.
__________ involves checking data from a sample to see if it provides evidence for or against a given claim about a population.
Hypothesis testing involves checking data from a __________ to see if it provides evidence for or against a given claim about a population.
Hypothesis testing involves checking data from a sample to see if it provides __________ for or against a given claim about a population.
Hypothesis testing involves checking data from a sample to see if it provides evidence for or against a given claim about a __________.
When data is __________, we make inferences about the population proportion p.
When data is categorical, we make inferences about the population __________ p.
When data is __________, we make inferences about the population mean μ.
When data is quantitative, we make __________ about the population mean μ.
When data is quantitative, we make inferences about the population __________ μ.
The __________ estimator for μ is x̄.
The point __________ for μ is x̄.
The point estimator for __________ is p̂.
The __________ of point estimators x̄ and p̂ increases as the sample size increases.
The accuracy of point __________ x̄ and p̂ increases as the sample size increases.
The accuracy of point estimators x̄ and p̂ __________ as the sample size __________.
The accuracy of point estimators x̄ and p̂ increases as the __________ increases.
The __________ estimator for σ<sup>2</sup>is s<sup>2</sup>.
The point __________ for σ<sup>2</sup>is s<sup>2</sup>.
Depending on the given level of confidence, we use __________, notated z*, to find the margin of error.
Depending on the given level of confidence, we use multipliers, notated z*, to find the __________.
The __________, notated m, represents the maximum estimation error for a given level of confidence.
The margin of error, notated __________, represents the maximum estimation error for a given level of confidence.
The margin of error, notated m, represents the __________ estimation error for a given level of confidence.
The multiplier for a confidence level of __________% is 1.
The multiplier for a confidence level of 68% is __________.
The multiplier for a confidence level of __________% is 2.
The multiplier for a confidence level of 95% is __________.
The multiplier for a confidence level of __________% is 3.
The multiplier for a confidence level of 99.7% is __________.
A __________ confidence interval will provide a less precise estimation of the true value of the population mean.
A wider __________ will provide a less precise estimation of the true value of the population mean.
A wider confidence interval will provide a __________ precise estimation of the true value of the population mean.
A wider confidence interval will provide a less precise __________ of the true value of the population mean.
If we want to __________ the precision of our confidence interval without compromising the confidence level itself, we can __________ the size of our sample.
If we want to increase the precision of our __________ without compromising the confidence level itself, we can increase the size of our sample.
If we want to __________ the precision of our confidence interval without compromising the confidence level itself, we can __________ the size of our sample.
If we want to increase the precision of our confidence interval without compromising the confidence level itself, we can increase the size of our __________.
__________ apply to the population proportion when the variable is categorical.
Confidence intervals apply to the population proportion when the variable is __________.
In __________, the first claim is the null hypothesis, notated H<sub>0</sub>.
In hypothesis testing, the first claim is the __________ hypothesis, notated H<sub>0</sub>.
In __________ testing, the second claim, typically what we suspect is happening, is the alternative __________, notated H<sub>a</sub>.
In hypothesis testing, the __________claim, typically what we suspect is happening, is the alternative hypothesis, notated H<sub>a</sub>.
In hypothesis testing, the second claim, typically what we suspect is happening, is the __________ hypothesis, notated H<sub>a</sub>.
The __________ the p-value we are given after testing, the more evidence we have against the null hypothesis.
The smaller the __________ we are given after testing, the more evidence we have against the null hypothesis.
The smaller the p-value we are given after testing, the more evidence we have __________ the null hypothesis.
The smaller the p-value we are given after testing, the more evidence we have against the __________.
The __________ tells us how likely or unlikely it is to get data like that observed if the null hypothesis is true.
The p-value tells us how likely or unlikely it is to get data like that observed if the __________ is true.
The p-value tells us how likely or unlikely it is to get data like that observed if the null hypothesis is __________.
The __________ of a hypothesis test, notated α, is the cutoff value we use to determine how unlikely our data must be to be able to reject the null hypothesis.
The significance level of a hypothesis test, notated α, is the __________ value we use to determine how unlikely our data must be to be able to reject the null hypothesis.
The significance level of a hypothesis test, notated α, is the cutoff value we use to determine how unlikely our data must be to be able to __________ the null hypothesis.
The significance level of a hypothesis test, notated α, is the cutoff value we use to determine how unlikely our data must be to be able to reject the __________hypothesis.
If our p-value is __________ than α, we reject the null hypothesis due to statistically significant results.
If our p-value is less than α, we __________ the null hypothesis due to statistically significant results.
If our p-value is less than α, we reject the null hypothesis due to statistically __________ results.
If our p-value is __________ than α, we cannot reject the null hypothesis and our results are not statistically significant.
If our p-value is greater than α, we cannot reject the null hypothesis and our results are not __________ significant.
If our __________is greater than α, we cannot reject the null hypothesis and our results are not statistically significant.
